object.title: Poster, Hurry!, 1997

participants.person_date: New York, New York, USA, founded 1993

object.justification:
Stefan Sagmeister is one of the most exciting graphic designers working today. This design is part of a group of objects proposed for acquisition that represents some of his best work from the mid-1990s to the present (2000).
Sagmeister was born in Austria and studied design in Austria and New York. He worked for Leo Burnett in Hong Kong and for M& Co. in New York before establishing his own New York-based firm in 1993. Since the mid-1990s, Sagmeister has been in demand as a CD cover designer due to his innovative aesthetic sensibility. His design work for the music industry has been recognized with both Grammy awards and design awards and is highly regarded by his clients (including Mick Jagger, Aerosmith, Lou Reed, Pat Metheny, and David Byrne) and the public. He has designed books with Lou Reed and David Byrne and, currently, is working on a book about his own work called Made You Look (to be published by Booth-Clibborn in March 2001).
Even though much of today's graphic design is made via computer, Sagmeister deliberately emphasizes the physicality of the body—often through handwriting and mark making—to reinforce the humanity of the design process and the human scale of interpersonal communication. Design is created by and for people, not machines. This is most literally manifested in his AIGA Detroit poster design, for which Sagmeister carved the program information onto his body. Sagmeister’s designs also invite participation, such as encouraging AIGA designers to personalize a 1997 New Orleans conference poster. His business card designs are also engineered for interaction—whether pulling out a card from its op art sleeve or using a pin hole to mimic a photographer's selective eye. His CD designs often involve an invented game or symbolic system for the consumer to play and solve as they listen to the music, as represented in his work for David Byrne and Pat Metheny.
The museum wishes to selectively acquire important design items to exemplify work by today's leading designers, particularly those who were represented in the museum's National Design Triennial in 2000. To demonstrate the variety of ways Sagmeister introduces a physical, personal, and interactive sensibility into his graphic design, this selection of his recent work is recommended for acquisition: two posters, a promotional brochure, three CD covers/packaging, two business cards, and a pop-up promotional postcard. Many of the pieces were exhibited in the Triennial.
object.description:
Poster (folded to be mailer brochure) to announce American Institute of Graphic Arts (AIGA) Fall 1997 Conference in New Orleans. Recto: Main image is color image of white headless chicken running in grassy terrain; six red drops of blood arranged around throat of chicken. At far left, brown-feathered headless chicken; trees at right. From upper right, in various text styles, "BUT, HURRY! (apprearance of font similar to chicken feet)/ Jambolaya/ THE DESIGN OF CULTURE/ MEETS/ THE CULTURE OF DESIGN/ THE 1997 BIENNIAL CONFERENCE/ OF THE AMERICAN INSTITUTE OF GRAPHIC ARTS/ NEW ORLEANS/ LOUISIANA/ NOV. 13-16, 1997" (in yellow).  Imprinted in handwritten cursive font around date arranged in three sections "NEW Orleans is/ THE AMERICAN MELTING POT/ AT A ROLLING BOIL,/ WHERE FRENCH, BRITISH,/ SPANISH, AFRICAN-AMERICAN/ AND NATIVE AMERICAN/ CULTURES HAVE COMBINED/ TO CREATE BREAKTHROUGHS/ IN MUSIC, ART/ LITERATURE AND FOOD./ WHAT BETTER PLACE/ FOR 2000 OF THE COUNTRY'S/ BEST GRAPHIC DESIGNERS/ TO MEET, TALK, EAT, DRINK,/ DANCE, ARGUE,think, AND LEARN/ HOW OUR WORK AFFECTS THE WORLD/ AND HOW THE WORL/ AFFECTS OUR WORK?/ (next section) FORGET ABOUT THE USUAL SUSPECTS WITH THE / SAME OLD SHOW-AND-TELL/ SLIDE SHOWS...THERE ARE DESIGN CONFERENCES YOU GO TO FOR/ INSPIRATION, AND THEN/ THERE ARE CONFERENCES/ THAT CHANGE YOUR LIFE./ THIS FALL'S AIGA CONFERENCE/ IN NEW ORLEANS WILL/ BE ALL THREE:/ DON'T EVEN THINK ABOUT MISSING IT".
At lower right corner, labels scattered with names of various participating designers. [To personalize and interact with the design, designers were asked to write their names or provide an image on a small label.]   At upper right corner, vertically in yellow, imprinted in handwrinting font, "WHY A HEADLESS CHICKEN? IS IT A METAPHOR FOR THE PROFESSION?/ SHOULD WE STOP RUNNING AROUND LIKE ONE AND SIGN UP/ FOR THIS VERY INTERESTING CONFERENCE?/ IS IT A VOODOO SYMBOL?/ ANTI TECHNOLOGY?/ WILL A MIXTURE OF TELEPHONE SCRIBBLES AND TURN OF THE CENTURY/ ART BRUT REALLY BE THE HOT NEW STYLE REPLACING WOOD VENEER/ ITSY-BITSY TYPE BOXES AND AROUND CORNERS? WASN'T NEW Simplicity SUPPOSED TO COME FIRST? EURO-TECHNO?"
Verso: Poster organized into 12 sections based on folds.  From from top left to right: 
Section 1: "ADDED ATTRACTIONS"
Section 2: "Main Stage speakers"
Section 3: for mailing, postage, mailing address, etc.
Section 4,8,12: "The Speakers. that WILL COME" followed by list of various designers participating in this event.
Section 5: "CONFERENCE/ Registration"
Section 6: "AFTERNOON PANEL DISCUSSION/ FRIDAY"
Section 7:"And always remember: Style=FART/ JAMBALAYA/ New Orleans"
Section 9: "AIGA Membership"
Section10: SATURDAY MORE AFTERNOON PANEL DISCUSSION"
Section11: "New Orleans Jambalaya" and color photographic reproduction of head of chicken. When folded, this page is cover page.
object.signed: Credits in yellow box at near center, right side, imprinted in blue: "Concept & DESIGN:/ SAGMEISTER INC, NEW YORK/ PHOTOGRAPH: BELA BORSODI/ PAINT BOX: DALTON PORTELLA/ A MAGIC GRAPHICS INC/ NEW YORK/ COLOR SEPS: + PRINTING/ WILLIAMSON PRINTING/ CORPORATION, DALLAS/ PAPER: 70# MOHAWK 50/10/ MATTE COATED".
object.inscribed: Imprinted in yellow, at lower right (below rear leg of chicken), "AIGA New Orleans Conference/ PRODUCTION:/ JANET ABRAMS, Program DIRECTOR/ ALANA COWAN, PRogram ASSISTANT... Conference Committee: Michael Bierut, Bill Drenttel, Steff Geissbuhler, Ric Grefe, SYLVIA HARRIS, JESSICA HELFAND/ CHEE PEARLMAN, Sominol QURAESHI, LUCILLE TENAZAS, MICHAEL VANDERBYL, LORRAINE WILD".
